newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam holds breath ahead of drug trial verdict.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam holds breath ahead of drug trial verdict.

text.p: Vietnam's biggest drugs scandal was set to reach its climax on Wednesday as a Hanoi court prepared to send security officials, border guards and other members of a trafficking ring either to jail or the firing squad.

Newspapers were packed with last-minute details of the two-week courtroom drama, whose central figures have become household names, and even the father of key defendant Vu Xuan Truong said his son deserved to die.
The trial of the 22 people, half of them former police and border security officials, is the biggest drugs scandal yet to surface in communist Vietnam.
The judges, whose 100-page verdict was due to be delivered late on Wednesday, were expected to follow a prosecution recommendation calling for eight people to be sentenced to death.
However, sources at the court said leniency might be shown towards two women who maintained their innocence throughout the proceedings.
Eight of the 14 others are expected to face life imprisonment, with the rest set for terms of up to 20 years.
Truong, a former captain in the Interior Ministry's anti-crime unit, has already accepted that he will die.

He has tried to commit suicide twice, first by dashing his head against the wall of his prison-cell wall and then by butting the corner of a water cistern, and has taken to wearing a white headband to mourn his own coming death.
Truong's father, Vu Van Vuong, told the Lao Dong newspaper that his son deserved to die. But he called for law to deal humanely with Truong's co-defendant wife and brother.
The drugs syndicate is believed to have flooded the country with an estimated 300 kg (660 pounds) of heroin from remote corners of Thailand, Laos and Burma over several years.
Drug experts say Vietnam has become a major transit route for narcotics from the notorious Golden Triangle since its borders, long closed to the outside world, were opened in the late 1980s.
Huge amounts of heroin have been shipped to destinations such as Australia, the United States, Hong Kong, Taiwan, often under the eye of corrupt officials.
Much has also stayed in Vietnam, where a decades-old habit of smoking opium is rapidly being replaced by addiction to heroin, even among children.
The daily Vietnam News said on Wednesday that boxes for anonymous letters, posted at schools around the capital, had helped identify pushers, selling points and drug users.

"...Through the system, 173 students were denounced as being addicted to drugs, 81 drug-dealing points adjacent to schools were named, and three touts who urged students to use drugs were identified," the paper said.
The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) said on Wednesday it would provide about $500,000 for a project to study the use of an anti-addiction herbal medication called HEANTOS.
While efforts may be under way to help addicts, little sympathy has been spared from either the government or the public at large for the trial's defendants.
"With Vu Xuan Truong people feel angry, but also sickened and disgusted," a man in the street told the Tuoi Tre newspaper. "With every cent that he put in his pocket, someone lost a life."
